official-title.#text:
To provide for the development and dissemination of evidence-based best practices for health care
			 professionals to recognize victims of a severe form of trafficking and
			 respond to such individuals appropriately, and for other purposes.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Trafficking Awareness Training for Health Care Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Trafficking Awareness Training for Health Care Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , acting through the Administrator of the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Secretary of Health and Human
			 Services

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, shall award, on a competitive basis, a grant to an
			 eligible school under which such school will—
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Agency for Healthcare
			 Research and Quality

text.#text: Not later than 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act, the

header.#text: Grant for development of best practices

text.#text:
not later than 6 months after receipt of the award, develop best practices for health care
			 professionals—
to recognize victims of a severe form of trafficking; and
to respond appropriately to such individuals;

in developing best practices under paragraph (1), survey, analyze, and evaluate existing best
			 practices that foster the practice of interprofessional collaboration,
			 including those used by industries other than the health care industry, to
			 determine the extent to which such existing best practices may be adapted
			 for use as part of the best practices under paragraph (1);

develop curricula, training modules, or materials to train health care professionals on the best
			 practices developed under paragraph (1);

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Department of Health and Human
			 Services

text.#text:
not later than 12 months after the receipt of the award, make a subgrant to one entity in each of
			 the 10 administrative regions of the

to conduct the pilot program at one or more eligible sites within the respective region, which may
			 include an eligible site that is a school-based health center; and
to complete the implementation and evaluation of such pilot program with a period of 6 months;

not later than 24 months after the receipt of the award, analyze the results of the pilot programs
			 conducted through subgrants under paragraph (4), including analyzing—

changes in the acquired skills, knowledge, and attitude of health care professionals resulting from
			 the implementation of the programs;
the number of victims of a severe form of trafficking who are recognized under the programs;

of those recognized, the number who received information or referrals for services offered through
			 the programs; and
of those who received such information or referrals—
the number who participated in followup services; and
the type of followup services received;

determine, using the results of the analysis under paragraph (5), the extent to which the best
			 practices developed under paragraph (1) are evidence-based; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Secretary of Health and Human Services

text.#text:
submit a comprehensive assessment of the pilot programs conducted through subgrants under paragraph
			 (4) to the
the best practices that are determined pursuant to paragraph (6) to be evidence-based; and

the best practices that are determined pursuant to such paragraph to require further review in
			 order to determine whether they are evidence-based.
The best practices developed through the grant awarded under subsection (a)—
shall address—
indicators to recognize victims of a severe form of trafficking;
application of Federal and State law with respect to victims of a severe form of trafficking;

patient safety and security, including the requirements of HIPAA privacy and security law as
			 applied to victims of a severe form of trafficking;
the management of medical records of patients who are victims of a severe form of trafficking;
public and private social services available for rescue, food, clothing, and shelter referrals;

the hotlines for reporting human trafficking maintained by the National Human Trafficking Resource
			 Center and the
assessment tools for the identification of victims of a severe form of trafficking; and
shall not address patient medical treatment.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Secretary
			 of Health and Human Services

Administrator of the
			 Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality

the best practices that
			 are identified by the school under subparagraphs (A) and (B) of subsection
			 (a)(7); and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Department of Health and Human Services

text.#text: post on the public website of the

disseminate to health care profession schools the best practices identified by the school under
			 subsection (a)(7)(A) and evaluation results.
In this Act:

term.#tail:
means a person employed by a health care provider who provides to patients information (including
			 information not related to medical treatment), scheduling, services, or
			 referrals.

No additional funds are authorized to be appropriated to carry out this Act and the amendments made
			 by this Act, and this Act and such amendments shall be carried out using
			 amounts otherwise available for such purpose.
